review.title: An Effective Algorithm for and Phase Transitions of the Directed Hamiltonian Cycle Problem
review.abstract: The Hamiltonian cycle problem (HCP) is an important combinatorial problem with applications in many areas. It is among the first problems used for studying intrinsic properties, including phase transitions, of combinatorial problems. While thorough theoretical and experimental analyses have been made on the HCP in undirected graphs, a limited amount of work has been done for the HCP in directed graphs (DHCP). The main contribution of this work is an effective algorithm for the DHCP. Our algorithm explores and exploits the close relationship between the DHCP and the Assignment Problem (AP) and utilizes a technique based on Boolean satisfiability (SAT). By combining effective algorithms for the AP and SAT, our algorithm significantly outperforms previous exact DHCP algorithms, including an algorithm based on the award-winning Concorde TSP algorithm. The second result of the current study is an experimental analysis of phase transitions of the DHCP, verifying and refining a known phase transition of the DHCP.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: An undirected graph G = (V, E) is Hamiltonian if it contains a Hamiltonian problem (HC 1979), a cycle that visits each vertex exactly once. In the face of a graph, the Hamiltonian Cycle Problem (HCP) is a problem to find or prove that no HC exists in the diagram. HCP's decision-making version was one of the first problems to be proven to be complete (Karp, 1972). HCP is a well-known problem with many applications in different fields, such as the Hamiltonian Cycle Game in game theory (Stojakovic, 2005), the problem of finding a knight's tour in artificial intelligence (Henderson & Apodaca, 2008), and DNA Physical Mapping in Biology (Grebinski & Kucherov, 1996). Much research has been done on HCP in unregulated graphics.

sections.heading: 2. The Algorithm
sections.text: Consider a directed, unweighted graph G = (V, E) with nodes V and edges E. For our purposes of solving DHCP, we consider the problem of determining whether or not there is a collection of cycles that may not necessarily be complete cycles, visiting each vertex exactly once. We call this problem a direct assignment problem, or DAP for short. Our algorithm investigates and uses the intrinsic relationship between the DHCP and the DAP. Specifically, the AP-SAT algorithm searches for a HC in the space of DAP solutions. It first solves the DAP. If the DAP solution forms a HC or no DAP solution exists, the algorithm ends. If the DAP solver returns a solution that is not HC, the algorithm then tries to patch the subcycles in the solution into a HC using the well-known Karp Steele patch method (Karp & Steele, 1985).

sections.heading: 2.5 Some General Remarks
sections.text: The AP-SAT algorithm consists of three main components, namely the AP step, the KSP step and the SAT step. It might be interesting to know which of these components is the most important schema. To do this, we have to distinguish between completeness and effectiveness of the algorithm. The only necessary step for completeness is the SAT step of Section 2.4. This step without all previous steps also leads to a correct DHCP algorithm. On the other hand, the AP-SAT algorithm is more effective if the steps of the KSP are frequently mentioned and the SAT step is mentioned only a few times. For example, if no DAP solution exists or an existing HC solution exists through the previous steps, the SAT part is not called at all.

sections.heading: 4. Summary
sections.text: The Hamilton Cycle Problem (HCP) is an important, canonical combinatorial problem. Surprisingly, no effective exact algorithm was developed for the HCP in directed graphs that we called directed HCP or DHCP. Our main result of this work is a novel and effective exact algorithm for DHCP. Our algorithm uses an existing algorithm for the assignment problem and an existing method for Boolean Satisfaction (SAT). Our work includes a new SAT formulation of the HCP and the AP that can potentially be extended to other problems such as the TSP. Our experimental results on random and real problem cases showed that our new algorithm is superior to four known algorithms, including an algorithm that utilizes the award-winning Concorde TSP algorithm. Furthermore, the transition result of the first phase was extended to verifiable problems and we later extended to the CDHP based on this work.
